questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation. He also reports occasional shortness of breath and chest pain. On examination, the patient has decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest. Chest X-ray is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Chilaiditi syndrome.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Bochdalek hernia: Typically presents at birth as a congenital defect , causing severe respiratory distress .
  • • Option A. Bochdalek hernia:
  • • birth as a congenital defect
  • • severe respiratory distress
  • • Option C. Morgagni hernia : Another type of diaphragmatic hernia , usually congenital , but less likely to cause these symptoms.
  • • Option C. Morgagni hernia
  • • diaphragmatic hernia
  • • congenital
  • • Option D. Large bowel obstruction: Would show dilated bowel loops and possibly air-fluid levels , but not typically associated with decreased breath sounds unless complicated by massive dilation.
  • • Option D. Large bowel obstruction:
  • • dilated bowel loops
  • • air-fluid levels
  • • decreased breath sounds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chilaiditi syndrome is diagnosed when symptomatic interposition of the colon between the liver and diaphragm is present, as suggested by the patient's symptoms and X-ray findings.
  • ➤ Chilaiditi syndrome
  • ➤ symptomatic interposition
  • ➤ colon
  • ➤ liver and diaphragm
  • ➤ X-ray findings.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-392, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-392, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: All of the following are true about e-FAST except?

options.label: A
options.text: Reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries

options.label: B
options.text: Stands for extended Focused assessment with sonography in trauma

options.label: C
options.text: Not reliable in patients with subcutaneous emphysema

options.label: D
options.text: Indicated in all stable and unstable patients

questions.correct_answer: A. Reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: States that e-FAST stands for extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma , which is correct . It is an extended form of the FAST exam that also includes evaluation for pneumothorax.
  • • Option B:
  • • e-FAST stands for extended Focused Assessment
  • • Sonography in Trauma
  • • correct
  • • Option C : Asserts that e-FAST is not reliable in patients with subcutaneous emphysema . This is true because subcutaneous air can hinder the transmission of ultrasound waves, making the assessment unreliable.
  • • Option C
  • • e-FAST
  • • not reliable
  • • subcutaneous emphysema
  • • Option D : Says that e-FAST is indicated in all stable and unstable patients , which is true . It is a rapid initial assessment tool for trauma patients to help identify the presence of free fluids that might require surgical intervention.
  • • Option D
  • • e-FAST
  • • stable and unstable patients
  • • true
  • • Limitations of FAST include-
  • • Limitations of FAST include-
  • • Diaphragm tears Retroperitoneal haemorrhage Bowel injuries Mesenteric injuries Minor injuries(<200ml) Subcutaneous emphysema and obesity
  • • Diaphragm tears
  • • Retroperitoneal haemorrhage
  • • Bowel injuries
  • • Mesenteric injuries
  • • Minor injuries(<200ml)
  • • Subcutaneous emphysema and obesity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ e-FAST is not reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries , as these injuries do not always produce free fluid or air and may be missed without more definitive imaging like a CT scan.
  • ➤ e-FAST
  • ➤ not reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries
  • ➤ injuries do not always produce free fluid

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a low-grade fever associated with loss of appetite and weight loss. A barium meal follow-through was done and is as shown. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ileocecal TB

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Colonic diverticulosis would show pouch-like outpouchings in the colon and doesn’t usually present with the narrowing or pulling up of the cecum.
  • • Option B: Colonic diverticulosis
  • • pouch-like outpouchings
  • • colon
  • • Option C: Crohn's disease can present with similar features to ileocecal TB , including strictures and bowel wall thickening , but Crohn's typically shows more segmental involvement with "skip lesions" and the presence of fistulas or abscesses.
  • • Option C: Crohn's disease
  • • similar features to ileocecal TB
  • • strictures and bowel wall thickening
  • • Option D: Carcinoma of the cecum would more likely present with an irregular mass or apple-core lesion on barium studies , which is not described in the given explanation.
  • • Option D: Carcinoma of the cecum
  • • present with an irregular mass
  • • apple-core lesion
  • • barium studies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The findings from the barium meal follow-through , along with the clinical symptoms, suggest a diagnosis of Ileocecal TB , characterized by a dilated proximal ileum , narrowed terminal ileum with a string sign , and a shrunken , pulled-up cecum .

questions.text: An incidental finding was noted on a NCCT abdomen performed for suspected renal calculus. What would be the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cholecystectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Reassure: While reassurance might be the next step for benign and non-consequential findings , a porcelain gallbladder is associated with a higher risk of gallbladder carcinoma , and reassurance alone is not appropriate in this case.
  • • Option A. Reassure:
  • • reassurance
  • • next step
  • • benign and non-consequential findings
  • • porcelain gallbladder
  • • higher risk of gallbladder carcinoma
  • • Option C. Right Nephrectomy: This would be an incorrect and excessive step as the finding is related to the gallbladder and not the kidney . There is no indication for nephrectomy based on the finding of a porcelain gallbladder.
  • • Option C. Right Nephrectomy:
  • • incorrect
  • • excessive step
  • • gallbladder
  • • not the kidney
  • • Option D. DSA and coiling: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) and coiling are interventions used for vascular abnormalities such as aneurysms or active bleeding , not for the management of a porcelain gallbladder.
  • • Option D. DSA and coiling:
  • • Digital subtraction angiography
  • • coiling
  • • vascular abnormalities
  • • aneurysms
  • • active bleeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The correct management for a porcelain gallbladder , characterized by gallbladder wall calcification and associated with an increased risk of cancer , is prophylactic cholecystectomy . This approach is to prevent the potential development of gallbladder carcinoma.

questions.text: The Following X-ray appearance is suggestive of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Chronic pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute pancreatitis: Typically presents on imaging with pancreatic edema and inflammation but without the calcifications seen in chronic pancreatitis. It can show less specific findings such as enlargement of the pancreas or peripancreatic fluid.
  • • Option A. Acute pancreatitis:
  • • imaging
  • • pancreatic edema
  • • inflammation
  • • without the calcifications
  • • Option C. Carcinoma pancreas: Often presents with a mass lesion , possible dilatation of the pancreatic duct due to obstruction , and at times, a double duct signs on ERCP, which is not evident in the image provided.
  • • Option C. Carcinoma pancreas:
  • • mass lesion
  • • dilatation of the pancreatic duct
  • • obstruction
  • • Option D. Ductal adenoma: Is a rare benign tumor and would not typically present with the diffuse calcifications associated with chronic pancreatitis. It might present as an incidental finding or with non-specific ductal changes on imaging.
  • • Option D. Ductal adenoma:
  • • rare benign tumor
  • • not typically present with the diffuse calcifications

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When an imaging study reveals calcifications along the pancreatic duct and parenchyma , chronic pancreatitis should be considered, especially in the context of a history of alcohol abuse or repeated bouts of acute pancreatitis.
  • ➤ imaging study reveals calcifications
  • ➤ pancreatic duct
  • ➤ parenchyma
  • ➤ chronic pancreatitis
  • ➤ alcohol abuse

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain and weight loss over the past few months. He reports that his pain is located in the upper abdomen and radiates to his back. He also reports a history of new-onset diabetes and jaundice. On examination, he is found to have hepatomegaly and an enlarged, palpable pancreas. Imaging studies reveal diffuse enlargement of the pancreas with a "sausage-like" appearance as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Autoimmune pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Chronic pancreatitis: This condition is a progressive inflammatory disease leading to irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue . Symptoms typically include chronic abdominal pain , steatorrhea , and diabetes due to the loss of endocrine function . Imaging may show calcifications, ductal changes, and atrophy but not usually diffuse enlargement.
  • • Option A. Chronic pancreatitis:
  • • progressive inflammatory disease
  • • irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue
  • • chronic abdominal pain
  • • steatorrhea
  • • diabetes
  • • loss of endocrine function
  • • Option C. Acute pancreatitis: Acute inflammation of the pancreas typically presents with sudden , severe upper abdominal pain radiating to the back , elevated pancreatic enzymes , and findings of edema or necrosis on imaging, but not diffuse enlargement of the pancreas.
  • • Option C. Acute pancreatitis:
  • • presents with sudden
  • • severe upper abdominal pain radiating to the back
  • • elevated pancreatic enzymes
  • • Option D. Metastatic carcinoma of the pancreas: While primary pancreatic cancer can cause a palpable mass , jaundice , and weight loss , metastatic cancer to the pancreas is less common . Imaging would likely show discrete lesions rather than diffuse enlargement.
  • • Option D. Metastatic carcinoma of the pancreas:
  • • primary pancreatic cancer
  • • cause a palpable mass
  • • jaundice
  • • weight loss
  • • metastatic cancer
  • • pancreas
  • • less common

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct diagnosis in this case is autoimmune pancreatitis , indicated by the patient's new-onset diabetes , jaundice , diffuse 'sausage-like' enlargement of the pancreas on imaging , and systemic symptoms . This condition is associated with an autoimmune response and often responds to corticosteroid therapy.
  • ➤ autoimmune pancreatitis
  • ➤ patient's new-onset diabetes
  • ➤ jaundice
  • ➤ diffuse 'sausage-like' enlargement
  • ➤ pancreas on imaging
  • ➤ systemic symptoms
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 370
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 370

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray shown below:
questions.correct_answer: B. Staghorn calculi of the kidneys
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Staghorn calculi of the kidneys

  • • not visible
  • • plain X-rays unless they are calcified

  • • Option C. Medullary nephrocalcinosis
  • • accumulation of calcium
  • • renal medulla
  • • X-ray
  • • appear as diffuse
  • • fine calcifications
  • • Option D. Putty kidney refers to renal tuberculosis leading to autonephrectomy where the kidney becomes non-functional and may calcify . The calcifications in a putty kidney are usually irregular and do not form a staghorn pattern.
  • • Option D. Putty kidney
  • • renal tuberculosis
  • • autonephrectomy
  • • kidney becomes non-functional
  • • may calcify

questions.text: A 28-year-old banker came in for a regular insurance check-up, in whom a hyperechoic renal lesion was incidentally detected on ultrasound after which he also underwent a CT. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.  Angiomyolipoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Angiomyolipoma of the kidney on CT appears as a well-defined mass within the kidney , often containing both fat (which appears as areas of low density) and denser regions due to blood vessels and muscle . Because of its composition , it can typically be diagnosed on non-contrast CT due to the presence of fat within the tumor .

questions.text: During intravenous pyelography of a patient, the left kidney could not be visualized. What condition is this suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Multi-cystic dysplastic kidney

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Duplicated collecting system:
  • • Option A. Duplicated collecting system:
  • • This refers to a congenital condition where two ureteric buds form on the same side , leading to a duplication of the collecting system . On imaging, two separate renal pelvices and ureters may be observed coming from one kidney. It can be complete or partial and may sometimes be associated with other urinary tract anomalies.
  • • This refers to a congenital condition where two ureteric buds form on the same side , leading to a duplication of the collecting system .
  • • congenital condition
  • • two ureteric buds
  • • same side
  • • duplication of the collecting system
  • • On imaging, two separate renal pelvices and ureters may be observed coming from one kidney.
  • • It can be complete or partial and may sometimes be associated with other urinary tract anomalies.
  • • Option B. Polycystic kidney disease:
  • • Option B. Polycystic kidney disease:
  • • A genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys . These cysts can disrupt the normal structure and function of the kidneys and can lead to kidney failure. On imaging, enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts are seen .
  • • A genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys .
  • • genetic disorder
  • • growth of numerous cysts
  • • kidneys
  • • These cysts can disrupt the normal structure and function of the kidneys and can lead to kidney failure.
  • • On imaging, enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts are seen .
  • • enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts are seen
  • • Option D. Renal hypoplasia:
  • • Option D. Renal hypoplasia:
  • • A developmental defect resulting in a smaller-sized kidney that contains fewer nephrons than normal . Can be due to a variety of genetic or environmental causes . On imaging, a smaller kidney with decreased parenchymal thickness is observed. The overall architecture of the kidney is preserved, unlike dysplastic conditions where the internal structure is disrupted.
  • • A developmental defect resulting in a smaller-sized kidney that contains fewer nephrons than normal .
  • • developmental defect
  • • smaller-sized kidney
  • • fewer nephrons than normal
  • • Can be due to a variety of genetic or environmental causes .
  • • variety of genetic or environmental causes
  • • On imaging, a smaller kidney with decreased parenchymal thickness is observed. The overall architecture of the kidney is preserved, unlike dysplastic conditions where the internal structure is disrupted.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multi-cystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK) is a condition where the kidney is replaced by multiple non-functioning cysts and no normal renal parenchyma .

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent epigastric pain radiating to the back and accompanied by nausea. She has had multiple hospital admissions due to these episodes. Her serum amylase and lipase are elevated during attacks. Imaging has shown no gallstones or common bile duct dilation. There is no history of alcohol abuse, and her recent attack did not have associated jaundice or evidence of cholangitis. Which of the following is least likely to be an indication for performing an Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Pancreatitis without features choledochal cyst or cholangitis

questions.correct_answer: D. Pancreatitis without features choledochal cyst or cholangitis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Pancreatitis without features choledochal cyst or cholangitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Recurrent pancreatitis: ERCP is often indicated in recurrent pancreatitis , especially when a biliary cause is suspected , such as choledocholithiasis , or to investigate anatomical anomalies that could predispose to pancreatitis, like pancreas divisum.
  • • Option A. Recurrent pancreatitis:
  • • ERCP
  • • indicated in recurrent pancreatitis
  • • biliary cause is suspected
  • • choledocholithiasis
  • • Option B. Periampullary carcinoma: ERCP is a crucial diagnostic tool for visualizing periampullary tumors that may cause obstruction , and it can also assist in stent placement to relieve jaundice.
  • • Option B. Periampullary carcinoma:
  • • ERCP
  • • diagnostic tool
  • • visualizing periampullary tumors
  • • cause obstruction
  • • Option C. Unexplained jaundice: ERCP is indicated for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in patients with jaundice when imaging studies suggest biliary obstruction , or the cause remains uncertain after other investigations.
  • • Option C. Unexplained jaundice:
  • • diagnostic and therapeutic purposes
  • • jaundice
  • • biliary obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ERCP is a specialized endoscopic technique used both for diagnosis and treatment of conditions involving the biliary and pancreatic ductal systems . It is not typically indicated for cases of pancreatitis unless there is a suspicion of biliary obstruction or other specific features that point towards a biliary etiology .

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain and fever. He reports a history of intermittent abdominal pain and nausea for the past few weeks. On examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 102.5°F and has tenderness in the right upper quadrant with a positive Murphy's sign. Laboratory investigations reveal an elevated white blood cell count, elevated liver enzymes, and an elevated blood glucose level. NCCT is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Calculous cholecystitis: Typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and fever . It involves inflammation of the gallbladder due to obstruction by gallstones but doesn't commonly involve gas-forming organisms as evidenced in the image.
  • • Option A. Calculous cholecystitis:
  • • right upper quadrant pain
  • • fever
  • • inflammation of the gallbladder
  • • obstruction by gallstones
  • • Option B. Acute pancreatitis: Presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back , elevated amylase and lipase levels , and would show pancreatic inflammation on imaging, not features of gallbladder air as seen.
  • • Option B. Acute pancreatitis:
  • • epigastric pain radiating to the back
  • • elevated amylase
  • • lipase levels
  • • Option C. Choledocholithiasis: Involves stones in the common bile duct , presenting with jaundice and possible pancreatitis , but it would not present with the gas pattern in the gallbladder wall shown.
  • • Option C. Choledocholithiasis:
  • • stones
  • • common bile duct
  • • jaundice
  • • possible pancreatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Emphysematous cholecystitis on imaging shows air in the gallbladder wall . It is a surgical emergency due to the risk of gallbladder gangrene and perforation , especially in diabetic patients.
  • ➤ Emphysematous cholecystitis
  • ➤ air in the gallbladder wall

  • ➤ risk of gallbladder gangrene
  • ➤ perforation
  • ➤ diabetic

  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No-354

questions.text: A person at the airport with symptoms showing agitations showed following x- ray findings. He was carrying enema apparatus and laxatives. Which of the following is a wrong statement?

options.label: D
options.text: He is at risk of poisoning

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. He is malingering

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Abdominal CT imaging is required. This is typically done to further evaluate the contents within the gastrointestinal tract that might not be clearly visible on an X-ray, especially when suspecting internal concealment of substances.
  • • Option A. Abdominal CT imaging is required.
  • • done to further evaluate the contents within the gastrointestinal tract
  • • Option C. He is a body packer. This is likely correct given the X-ray findings and the presence of enema apparatus and laxatives , which are indicative of someone attempting to smuggle drugs internally.
  • • Option C. He is a body packer.
  • • X-ray findings and the presence of enema apparatus and laxatives
  • • Option D. He is at risk of poisoning. This is a correct statement as body packers are at risk of packet rupture , which can lead to severe poisoning or overdose.
  • • Option D. He is at risk of poisoning.
  • • body packers are at risk of packet rupture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The individual is not malingering but is exhibiting signs of being a body packer , a condition where drugs are internally concealed for smuggling , posing a significant risk of poisoning if the packets rupture .
  • ➤ individual is not malingering
  • ➤ exhibiting signs of being a body packer
  • ➤ drugs are internally concealed for smuggling
  • ➤ posing
  • ➤ poisoning if the packets rupture

questions.text: A 1-day-old male infant presents to the emergency department with symptoms of abdominal distention, vomiting, and bilious vomit. The baby's mother reports that the baby has been feeding poorly since birth and has not passed any meconium stool. The baby appears irritable, with a distended abdomen and visible peristalsis. The healthcare team orders immediate imaging studies and consultation with a pediatric surgeon. The upper GI contrast study is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Midgut volvulus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Duodenal atresia : Typically presents with a 'double bubble' sign on imaging due to obstruction at the level of the duodenum , not involving twisting of the bowel as seen in the image.
  • • Option A. Duodenal atresia
  • • 'double bubble' sign
  • • imaging
  • • obstruction at the level of the duodenum
  • • Option B. Intussusception : Occurs more commonly in older children and would typically present with a 'target sign' on ultrasound , not involving twisting of the bowel.
  • • Option B. Intussusception
  • • older children
  • • 'target sign' on ultrasound
  • • Option D: Hirschsprung disease – Characterized by colonic obstruction due to absence of ganglion cells , typically not presenting with twisting of the bowel.
  • • Option D: Hirschsprung disease
  • • colonic obstruction
  • • absence of ganglion cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Midgut volvulus , characterized by the 'corkscrew sign' on contrast study , is a surgical emergency that requires prompt intervention to prevent bowel ischemia and necrosis .
  • ➤ Midgut volvulus
  • ➤ 'corkscrew sign'
  • ➤ contrast study
  • ➤ surgical emergency
  • ➤ prompt intervention
  • ➤ bowel ischemia
  • ➤ necrosis
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-400, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with abdominal cramping, fever, and watery diarrhea. She recently completed a course of antibiotics for a urinary tract infection. Stool culture is negative for bacterial pathogens, but stool toxin assay is positive. His CT abdomen was performed which is given below. What is the patient most likely suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Pseudomembranous colitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Crohn's disease typically shows on CT as segmental bowel wall thickening , strictures, and the presence of "skip lesions." The accordion sign is not characteristic of Crohn's disease.
  • • Option A: Crohn's disease
  • • CT as segmental bowel wall thickening
  • • presence of "skip lesions."
  • • Option B: Ulcerative colitis usually presents with continuous colonic involvement starting from the rectum with uniform wall thickening and loss of haustral pattern on CT . It does not typically present with the accordion sign.
  • • Option B: Ulcerative colitis
  • • presents
  • • continuous colonic involvement
  • • starting
  • • rectum
  • • uniform wall thickening
  • • loss of haustral pattern on CT
  • • Option C: (Toxic megacolon) is a severe complication of colitis , marked by extreme dilation of the colon on imaging , along with signs of systemic toxicity . While wall thickening may be present, the accordion sign is not the defining feature.
  • • Option C: (Toxic megacolon)
  • • complication of colitis
  • • extreme dilation
  • • colon on imaging
  • • systemic toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The CT image showing the accordion sign , along with the clinical presentation of recent antibiotic use , diarrhea , positive stool toxin assay , and fever , strongly suggests the diagnosis of Pseudomembranous colitis associated with Clostridium difficile infection .
  • ➤ CT image
  • ➤ accordion sign
  • ➤ clinical presentation of recent antibiotic use
  • ➤ diarrhea
  • ➤ positive stool toxin assay
  • ➤ fever
  • ➤ Pseudomembranous colitis
  • ➤ Clostridium difficile infection
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-294, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-294, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 2-month-old female infant presents to the emergency department with jaundice and pale stools since birth. The mother reports that the infant has been feeding poorly and has lost weight over the past week. On examination, the infant appears jaundiced with a palpable liver edge. Laboratory tests show elevated bilirubin levels and a direct bilirubin fraction greater than 20%. Ultrasound imaging reveals a small, contracted gallbladder. The liver appearance is shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Biliary atresia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Galactosemia: Is a rare genetic metabolic disorder where the body is unable to metabolize the sugar galactose properly . While it can present with jaundice in the newborn period , it is also associated with other symptoms such as poor feeding, vomiting, and development of cataracts, not typically with a palpable liver edge or a specific finding on ultrasound imaging of the liver.
  • • Option A. Galactosemia:
  • • rare genetic metabolic disorder
  • • body is unable to metabolize the sugar galactose properly
  • • jaundice
  • • newborn period
  • • Option C. Hemangioma: Is a common benign liver tumor in infants . It does not typically present with jaundice or pale stools unless there is a complication such as Kasabach-Merritt syndrome, which is rare.
  • • Option C. Hemangioma:
  • • common benign liver tumor
  • • infants
  • • Option D. Caroli's disease: Is a rare congenital disorder characterized by non-obstructive saccular or fusiform dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts . Patients may present with recurrent abdominal pain, cholangitis, or signs of portal hypertension, but not typically with direct hyperbilirubinemia or early life jaundice.
  • • Option D. Caroli's disease:
  • • rare congenital disorder
  • • non-obstructive saccular
  • • fusiform dilatation
  • • intrahepatic bile ducts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Biliary atresia can be diagnosed in an infant presenting with persistent jaundice , pale stools , hepatomegaly , and a contracted gallbladder on imaging . Biliary atresia should be suspected in any infant with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and characteristic ultrasound findings.
  • ➤ Biliary atresia
  • ➤ diagnosed in an infant
  • ➤ persistent jaundice
  • ➤ pale stools
  • ➤ hepatomegaly
  • ➤ contracted gallbladder
  • ➤ imaging
  • ➤ Biliary atresia
  • ➤ infant
  • ➤ conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 362
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 362

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with complaints of right upper quadrant pain and nausea. She has a history of oral contraceptive use for several years. On physical examination, she has mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Her laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes. Imaging studies reveal a 5 cm hepatic mass in the right lobe of the liver as shown in the CECT. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hepatic adenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) : This is a primary liver cancer , which is often a result of chronic liver disease , such as cirrhosis due to hepatitis B , hepatitis C , or alcohol use . HCC may present as a solitary mass or multiple nodules and can exhibit arterial phase enhancement on imaging.
  • • Option A.
  • • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • • primary liver cancer
  • • chronic liver disease
  • • cirrhosis due to hepatitis B
  • • hepatitis C
  • • alcohol use
  • • Option B . Metastatic infiltrates: These are secondary cancerous growths that have spread to the liver from other primary sites of cancer . They can vary in appearance but often present as multiple lesions with variable enhancement patterns on imaging studies.
  • • Option B
  • • Metastatic infiltrates:
  • • secondary cancerous growths
  • • spread to the liver from other primary sites of cancer
  • • Option D. Hemangioma: This is the most common benign liver tumor . It is typically asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging . Hemangiomas are characteristically bright on T2-weighted MRI and show a typical pattern of peripheral nodular enhancement with progressive centripetal filling on contrast-enhanced studies.
  • • Option D.
  • • Hemangioma:
  • • benign liver tumor
  • • asymptomatic
  • • incidentally on imaging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatic adenoma is most likely seen in young women on oral contraceptives and presents as an enhancing lesion on arterial phase imaging.
  • ➤ Hepatic adenoma
  • ➤ young women on oral contraceptives
  • ➤ arterial phase imaging.
  • ➤ Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 322
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 322

questions.text: A primigravida with 18 weeks POG presents to the clinic for an anomaly scan. Oligohydramnios is noted with bladder shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Posterior urethral valves

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD) : This is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys . In utero , enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts might be visualized . It does not typically present with a "keyhole sign" on ultrasound.
  • • Option A.
  • • Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD)
  • • genetic disorder
  • • growth of numerous cysts
  • • kidneys
  • • utero
  • • enlarged kidneys
  • • multiple cysts
  • • visualized
  • • Simple renal cysts will appear anechoic with well-defined thin walls , posterior acoustic enhancement
  • • Simple renal cysts
  • • anechoic with well-defined thin walls
  • • posterior acoustic enhancement
  • • Option B. Hydronephrosis : This condition involves the swelling of one kidney due to a buildup of urine . It occurs when urine cannot drain from the kidney to the bladder from a blockage or obstruction . Sonographically, it would show as an enlargement of the renal pelvis and calyces and not a "keyhole sign."
  • • Option B.
  • • Hydronephrosis
  • • swelling of one kidney
  • • buildup of urine
  • • urine
  • • cannot drain from the kidney
  • • bladder
  • • blockage or obstruction
  • • Hydronephrosis : dilated pelvicalyceal system
  • • Hydronephrosis
  • • Option C. Chronic Pyelonephritis : This is a long-standing infection that leads to scarring and deformation of the kidney . Chronic pyelonephritis would show irregular, echogenic kidneys on ultrasound, which is not consistent with the provided sonographic image.
  • • Option C.
  • • Chronic Pyelonephritis
  • • long-standing infection
  • • leads to scarring
  • • deformation of the kidney
  • • Chronic Pyelonephritis: Irregular and heterogeneous echotexture of renal parenchyma
  • • Chronic Pyelonephritis: Irregular and heterogeneous echotexture of renal parenchyma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The keyhole sign is an ultrasonographic sign seen in boys with posterior urethral valves . It refers to the appearance of the proximal urethra (which is dilated) and associated thick-walled distended bladder which on ultrasound may resemble a key hole.
  • ➤ keyhole sign
  • ➤ ultrasonographic
  • ➤ boys with posterior urethral valves
  • ➤ appearance of the proximal urethra
  • ➤ thick-walled distended bladder
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 466
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 466

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presenting with sterile pyuria. Radiograph is shown identify the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Putty kidney

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Nephrocalcinosis: It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in the renal parenchyma . The calcification is usually diffuse and involves the cortex and medulla . It's often associated with hypercalcemic conditions, but the patient does not present with a ground-glass appearance on radiography.
  • • Option A.
  • • Nephrocalcinosis:
  • • deposition of calcium salts
  • • renal parenchyma
  • • calcification
  • • diffuse
  • • cortex and medulla
  • • Option C. Staghorn calculus: This refers to a large renal calculus that conforms to the shape of the renal pelvis and calyces , resembling the antlers of a stag . It typically causes a branched radiopaque pattern on radiography, which is not demonstrated in the image provided.
  • • Option C.
  • • Staghorn calculus:
  • • large renal calculus
  • • conforms to the shape of the renal pelvis
  • • calyces
  • • antlers of a stag
  • • Option D. Psoas Calcification: This is usually secondary to chronic processes such as infection or hematoma , resulting in calcification within the psoas muscle . It would appear along the course of the psoas muscle and not within the kidney.
  • • Option D.
  • • Psoas Calcification:
  • • secondary to chronic processes
  • • infection or hematoma
  • • calcification
  • • psoas muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radiographic characteristics of a putty kidney , are homogenous , ground glass-like calcification , typically associated with renal tuberculosis.
  • ➤ radiographic
  • ➤ putty kidney
  • ➤ homogenous
  • ➤ ground glass-like calcification
  • ➤ renal tuberculosis.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Multiple enchondromas: Maffucci syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Multiple osteochondromas: multiple hereditary exostoses - Multiple hereditary exostoses are characterized by the presence of numerous osteochondromas , which are bony protrusions capped by cartilage . These typically arise on the external surface of bones , especially long bones, and are not usually seen within the short tubular bones of the hands as shown in the image.
  • • Option A. Multiple osteochondromas: multiple hereditary exostoses -
  • • presence of numerous osteochondromas
  • • bony protrusions capped by cartilage
  • • external surface of bones
  • • Option C. Multiple enchondromas: Ollier syndrome - Ollier disease is a nonhereditary skeletal disorder characterized by multiple enchondromas confined to one side of the body , predominantly affecting the limbs . Unlike Maffucci syndrome, Ollier disease does not involve soft tissue hemangiomas.
  • • Option C. Multiple enchondromas: Ollier syndrome -
  • • nonhereditary skeletal disorder
  • • multiple enchondromas
  • • confined to one side
  • • body
  • • affecting the limbs
  • • Option D. Multiple FD: McCune Albright syndrome - McCune-Albright syndrome is characterized by fibrous dysplasia (FD), café-au-lait spots , and endocrine abnormalities . Fibrous dysplasia causes abnormal fibrous growths in place of normal bone, which is not what the radiographs show.
  • • Option D. Multiple FD: McCune Albright syndrome -
  • • fibrous dysplasia
  • • café-au-lait spots
  • • endocrine abnormalities

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radiographs demonstrate multiple enchondromas along with phleboliths in the soft tissues , findings that are indicative of Maffucci syndrome . This syndrome is characterized by the presence of both enchondromas and soft tissue hemangiomas .
  • ➤ radiographs demonstrate multiple enchondromas
  • ➤ phleboliths
  • ➤ soft tissues
  • ➤ Maffucci syndrome
  • ➤ presence of both enchondromas
  • ➤ soft tissue hemangiomas

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty swallowing for the past few months. He reports feeling as if food is getting stuck in his chest and he has to drink liquids to help it go down. He also reports regurgitation of undigested food and occasional chest pain. He denies any weight loss, heartburn, or reflux symptoms. On examination, his vital signs are within normal limits, and he appears well-nourished. Auscultation of the lungs is clear, and there are no abdominal masses or hepatosplenomegaly. A barium swallow study is ordered, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Achalasia cardia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Diffuse esophageal spasm would show a corkscrew appearance on imaging, not seen here.
  • • Option A:
  • • Diffuse esophageal spasm
  • • corkscrew appearance
  • • Option B: A hiatus hernia would show a protrusion of the stomach through the diaphragm into the thorax .
  • • Option B:
  • • hiatus hernia
  • • protrusion
  • • stomach
  • • diaphragm
  • • thorax
  • • Option D: Carcinoma of the esophagus usually shows as an irregular narrowing or a stricture , commonly with a "rat-tail" appearance , which is not apparent in this image.
  • • Option D:
  • • Carcinoma
  • • esophagus
  • • irregular narrowing
  • • stricture
  • • "rat-tail" appearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The barium swallow study demonstrates a "bird-beak" sign , indicating achalasia cardia , a condition characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax and the absence of normal esophageal peristalsis
  • ➤ barium swallow
  • ➤ "bird-beak" sign
  • ➤ achalasia cardia
  • ➤ failure of the lower esophageal sphincter
  • ➤ relax
  • ➤ absence of normal esophageal peristalsis

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient came to ER with the complaint of severe abdominal pain. CTA was performed which is given below. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: An abscess in the psoas muscle

questions.correct_answer: B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer: A ruptured gastric ulcer typically presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that may radiate to the back . On imaging, especially CT , we might see evidence of perforation with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum). This finding is not consistent with the provided CTA image.
  • • Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer:
  • • presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain
  • • radiate to the back
  • • especially CT
  • • perforation with free air
  • • diaphragm
  • • Option C. Acute appendicitis : Patients with acute appendicitis typically present with abdominal pain that begins around the navel and later localizes to the lower right abdomen , accompanied by fever and leukocytosis . A CTA would show an enlarged, inflamed appendix, potentially with an appendicolith (a calcified deposit), but no contrast extravasation outside the aorta as seen in the provided image.
  • • Option C. Acute appendicitis
  • • abdominal pain
  • • begins around the navel
  • • localizes to the lower right abdomen
  • • fever and leukocytosis
  • • enlarged, inflamed appendix,
  • • appendicolith
  • • Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle: A psoas abscess would typically present with flank pain , fever , and a palpable mass , or difficulty with movements that involve the psoas muscle . On CTA, an abscess may appear as a well-defined fluid collection with possible enhancement after contrast administration. Again, this does not match the findings in the CTA image provided.
  • • Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle:
  • • psoas abscess
  • • present with flank pain
  • • fever
  • • palpable mass
  • • difficulty with movements
  • • psoas muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The correct diagnosis is B - A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The provided CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta , indicative of extraluminal contrast from a ruptured aortic aneurysm . This is an urgent surgical emergency requiring immediate attention.
  • ➤ CTA shows a soft tissue density
  • ➤ contrast visible
  • ➤ outside
  • ➤ left side
  • ➤ abdominal aorta
  • ➤ extraluminal contrast
  • ➤ ruptured aortic aneurysm
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 200.
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 200.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of short stature. The parents are of average height and deny any family history of dwarfism. On physical examination, the child has a large head with a prominent forehead, short arms and legs, and a broad, flattened nasal bridge. His fingers are short and stubby, and he has a prominent belly. X-rays is shown here. . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Achondroplasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis characterized by developmental delay , corneal clouding , and organomegaly . Skeletal abnormalities include dysostosis multiplex, which differs from the findings in this X-ray.
  • • Option A. Hurler Syndrome:
  • • mucopolysaccharidosis
  • • developmental delay
  • • corneal clouding
  • • organomegaly
  • • Option B. Marfan Syndrome: Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder presenting with tall stature , arachnodactyly, ectopia lentis , and cardiovascular abnormalities , which does not correlate with the clinical features or X-ray findings of this patient.
  • • Option B. Marfan Syndrome:
  • • connective tissue disorder
  • • tall stature
  • • arachnodactyly, ectopia lentis
  • • cardiovascular abnormalities
  • • Option D. Turner Syndrome: Turner syndrome affects females and presents with short stature , shield chest , and gonadal dysgenesis . This syndrome does not typically present with the skeletal findings observed in the X-ray.
  • • Option D. Turner Syndrome:
  • • affects females
  • • presents with short stature
  • • shield chest
  • • gonadal dysgenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of short stature , macrocephaly with frontal bossing , rhizomelic limb shortening , and the characteristic "champagne glass pelvis" on X-ray is diagnostic of Achondroplasia , which is a genetic disorder resulting in the most common form of disproportionate short stature.
  • ➤ short stature
  • ➤ macrocephaly
  • ➤ frontal bossing
  • ➤ rhizomelic limb shortening
  • ➤ "champagne glass pelvis" on X-ray
  • ➤ Achondroplasia
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 648
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 648

  • • Option D: Trisomy 13 is associated with several congenital abnormalities but, like Trisomy 18, it does not have a strong correlation with the "double bubble" sign as does Trisomy 21.

questions.text: A woman presents for evaluation of infertility. Her physician has ordered a diagnostic imaging test . An image from the test is provided. What is the name of the investigation shown in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Conventional HSG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . MR HSG refers to magnetic resonance hysterosalpingography , which is not typically used in routine infertility evaluations due to its complexity and cost.
  • • Option A
  • • MR HSG
  • • magnetic resonance hysterosalpingography
  • • Option B. Falloscopy is an invasive tool to study the fallopian tubes.
  • • Option B. Falloscopy
  • • invasive tool
  • • Option D . USG HSG would imply ultrasound hysterosalpingography , a less common method that might use saline or contrast-enhanced fluid to visualize the uterus and fallopian tubes but does not provide as detailed an image as conventional HSG.
  • • Option D
  • • USG HSG
  • • ultrasound hysterosalpingography
  • • less common method
  • • use saline
  • • contrast-enhanced fluid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the obstetrics clinic for a routine ultrasound at 12 weeks gestation. The ultrasound reveals a twin pregnancy. What is the type of twin pregnancy on the basis of the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Dichorionic diamniotic twins

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Monochorionic diamniotic twins share a single chorionic sac but have separate amniotic sacs , typically indicated by a 'T sign' on ultrasound.
  • • Option A. Monochorionic diamniotic twins share
  • • single chorionic sac
  • • separate amniotic sacs
  • • Option C. Dichorionic monoamniotic twins have separate chorions but share a single amniotic sac , which is extremely rare and usually not compatible with survival.
  • • Option C. Dichorionic monoamniotic twins
  • • separate chorions
  • • share a single amniotic sac
  • • Option D. Monochorionic monoamniotic twins share both the chorionic and amniotic sacs , presenting a high-risk situation with no intervening membrane.
  • • Option D. Monochorionic monoamniotic twins
  • • both the chorionic and amniotic sacs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The ultrasound shows the 'twin peak' or lambda (λ) sign , which is characteristic of dichorionic diamniotic twins . This signifies that each twin has its own chorionic and amniotic sac, the most common and least complicated type of twin pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman undergoes her first-trimester ultrasound screening to assess fetal development. What is the earliest detectable anomaly on ultrasound in a developing fetus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.  Anencephaly

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Spina bifida is a defect in the spinal column where the backbone and membranes around the spinal cord do not close completely. This can typically be detected in the second trimester.

  • • backbone
  • • membranes around the spinal cord
  • • close completely.
  • • Option C. Meningocele is a type of spina bifida where the protective membranes around the spinal cord push out through the vertebral opening , forming a sac filled with fluid . It is usually detected during the second trimester.
  • • Option C. Meningocele
  • • type of spina bifida
  • • protective membranes
  • • spinal cord push out
  • • vertebral opening
  • • sac filled with fluid
  • • Option D. Horseshoe kidney , where the kidneys fuse together to form a U-shape , is generally diagnosed during the second or third trimester.
  • • Option D. Horseshoe kidney
  • • kidneys fuse together
  • • U-shape

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Anencephaly is the earliest detectable anomaly on ultrasound , usually identifiable by 10-11 weeks of gestation , characterized by the absence of the cranial vault and significant portions of the brain.Top of Form
  • ➤ Anencephaly
  • ➤ earliest detectable anomaly on ultrasound
  • ➤ identifiable by 10-11 weeks of gestation
  • ➤ absence of the cranial vault
  • ➤ The characteristic findings of anencephaly on ultrasound include the absence of brain parenchymal tissue above the orbits , an absent calvarium , and disorganized brain parenchyma with acrania.

  • ➤ orbits
  • ➤ absent calvarium
  • ➤ In the coronal plane , the absence of cranial bone and brain may cause a "frog eye" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance due to the bulging orbits . Additionally, polyhydramnios, an excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid, may be present.

  • ➤ absence of cranial bone

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida presents to the obstetrics clinic at 32 weeks gestation with complaints of decreased fetal movements. The fundal height measurement is consistent with 28 weeks of gestation, and ultrasound confirms a diagnosis of IUGR. Which among the following is the false statement regarding Antenatal Doppler analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduction in end diastolic flow is associated with poor outcome

options.label: B
options.text: Notching in uterine artery tracing can predict early-onset preeclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: MCA tracing is the most sensitive marker for IUGR

options.label: D
options.text: S/D ratio of umbilical artery is high in IUGR

questions.correct_answer: C. MCA tracing is the most sensitive marker for IUGR
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. MCA tracing is the most sensitive marker for IUGR

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Reduction in end diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler indicates increased placental resistance , which is associated with poor fetal outcomes , including IUGR.
  • • Option A.
  • • Reduction in end diastolic flow
  • • umbilical artery Doppler
  • • increased placental resistance
  • • poor fetal outcomes
  • • Option B. Uterine artery Doppler can demonstrate notching , particularly in the early second trimester , which has been associated with an increased risk of developing preeclampsia.
  • • Option B. Uterine artery Doppler
  • • demonstrate notching
  • • early second trimester
  • • Option D. A high S/D ratio in the umbilical artery Doppler indicates increased placental resistance , which is commonly seen in cases of IUGR.
  • • Option D.
  • • A high S/D ratio in the umbilical artery Doppler
  • • increased placental resistance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the evaluation of a fetus with suspected IUGR , a high S/D ratio and reduction in end diastolic flow on umbilical artery Doppler are associated with the condition and poor fetal outcomes , whereas the MCA Doppler is not a sensitive marker for IUGR, but rather for fetal anemia.
  • ➤ evaluation of a fetus
  • ➤ suspected IUGR
  • ➤ high S/D ratio
  • ➤ reduction in end diastolic flow
  • ➤ umbilical artery Doppler
  • ➤ poor fetal outcomes
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition
  • ➤ Ref : Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for her first prenatal visit at 11 weeks of gestation. On transvaginal ultrasound, a gestational sac is seen measuring 28mm in diameter, but no yolk sac or fetal pole is identified. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Blighted ovum.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterine cavity , often in a fallopian tube. Ultrasound findings might include an adnexal mass or an empty uterus, but not a normal intrauterine gestational sac.
  • • Option B.
  • • An ectopic pregnancy
  • • fertilized egg implants outside the uterine cavity
  • • Option C. A molar pregnancy , a form of gestational trophoblastic disease , would show a characteristic 'snowstorm' or 'cluster of grapes' appearance on ultrasound due to the proliferation of abnormal trophoblastic tissue, rather than a normal gestational sac without a yolk sac or fetal pole.
  • • Option C.
  • • A molar pregnancy
  • • form of gestational trophoblastic disease
  • • 'snowstorm' or 'cluster of grapes' appearance
  • • Option D. In an early intrauterine pregnancy, especially by 11 weeks of gestation , both a yolk sac and fetal pole should be visible within the gestational sac on ultrasound.
  • • Option D. In an early intrauterine pregnancy,
  • • 11 weeks of gestation
  • • yolk sac
  • • fetal pole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The absence of both a yolk sac and a fetal pole within a gestational sac measuring 25mm or more in diameter on transvaginal ultrasound is diagnostic of a blighted ovum , indicating an early pregnancy failure .
  • ➤ absence of both a yolk sac
  • ➤ fetal pole
  • ➤ gestational sac measuring 25mm
  • ➤ more in diameter
  • ➤ transvaginal ultrasound
  • ➤ blighted ovum
  • ➤ early pregnancy failure
  • ➤ Ref :– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 36-week gestation newborn is born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 28-year-old primigravida mother. The pregnancy was uneventful with normal antenatal ultrasound findings. The newborn is noted to have respiratory distress immediately after delivery and is quickly transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for further evaluation and management. On examination, the neonate is tachypneic with subcostal retractions and decreased breath sounds on the left side. CXR is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct diagnosis is congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which presents with respiratory distress and is confirmed by the presence of abdominal organs in the thoracic cavity on X-ray. Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to the risk of gastrointestinal perforation and worsening respiratory distress.
  • ➤ The correct diagnosis is congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which presents with respiratory distress and is confirmed by the presence of abdominal organs in the thoracic cavity on X-ray.
  • ➤ Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to the risk of gastrointestinal perforation and worsening respiratory distress.
  • ➤ Note – Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia
  • ➤ Note

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reports a recent history of non-compliance with his prescribed proton pump inhibitor medication. On examination, he appears pale and has a rigid abdomen with rebound tenderness. CXR of the patient is shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Admit the patient to the ward and observe

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Perform immediate exploratory laparotomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Admission for observation is not appropriate for a surgical emergency indicated by free air under the diaphragm.
  • • Option A:
  • • Admission for observation
  • • not
  • • surgical emergency
  • • Option B: While intravenous antibiotics are part of the management , they are not the immediate next step given the need for urgent surgery.
  • • Option B:
  • • intravenous antibiotics
  • • part of the management
  • • Option D: Administration of analgesia and proton pump inhibitors is secondary to addressing the cause of the perforation surgically.
  • • Option D:
  • • Administration of analgesia
  • • proton pump inhibitors
  • • secondary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with a rigid abdomen and radiographic evidence of free air , suggesting a perforated peptic ulcer , the immediate next step is exploratory laparotomy to address the perforation.
  • ➤ rigid abdomen
  • ➤ radiographic evidence of free air
  • ➤ perforated peptic ulcer
  • ➤ exploratory laparotomy
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-252, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)
  • ➤ Ref: Page no-252, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of left lower quadrant abdominal pain that has been present for several days. He also reports constipation, bloating, and occasional rectal bleeding. On examination, there is tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the likely diagnosis based on his barium enema?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Sigmoid diverticulosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Sigmoid volvulus would present with severe abdominal pain and distention , and a plain abdominal X-ray would show a characteristic "coffee bean" sign. S
  • • Option B:

  • • severe abdominal pain
  • • distention
  • • plain abdominal X-ray
  • • "coffee bean"
  • • Option C: Sigmoid diverticulitis would present with fever, leukocytosis , and localized abdominal pain , and imaging would show evidence of inflammation or abscess formation.
  • • Option C:
  • • Sigmoid diverticulitis
  • • fever, leukocytosis
  • • localized abdominal pain
  • • imaging
  • • Option D: Colorectal cancer would typically present with a change in bowel habits , rectal bleeding , and possible mass on digital rectal examination or imaging. Which of the following condition shows ‘Saw tooth appearance’ on abdominal barium enema X-ray.
  • • Option D:
  • • Colorectal cancer
  • • change in bowel habits
  • • rectal bleeding
  • • mass on digital rectal
  • • ‘Saw tooth appearance’ on abdominal barium enema X-ray.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sigmoid diverticulosis is characterized by the presence of multiple diverticula seen in the sigmoid colon on barium enema imaging , consistent with the symptoms and the X-ray findings shown for the patient. This condition is associated with symptoms like constipation , bloating , and occasional rectal bleeding .

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe left upper quadrant (LUQ) pain after being punched by his colleague in a fight. His blood pressure is 110/76mmHg, his pulse is 80 bpm, and his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. Which of the following will be the best investigation in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. CT of the abdomen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

  • • Option B. Upper GI series : Typically used for evaluating the upper gastrointestinal tract , not for acute trauma assessment.
  • • Option B. Upper GI series
  • • evaluating the upper gastrointestinal tract
  • • Option C. E-FAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) : A rapid bedside ultrasound examination to evaluate for free fluid and air ; useful in trauma but may not be as definitive as a CT scan.
  • • Option C. E-FAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma)
  • • evaluate for free fluid and air

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CT of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating abdominal trauma in stable patients , providing detailed assessment to rule out significant internal injuries.

questions.text: A patient with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain presents to the emergency department. The patient is hypotensive, tachycardic, and appears to be in distress. A chest x-ray is performed and shows free air under the diaphragm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Perforated peptic ulcer.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute pancreatitis : Usually presents with epigastric pain that can radiate to the back , not typically associated with free air under the diaphragm.

  • • Option B. Mesenteric ischemia
  • • abdominal pain
  • • lead to bowel infarction
  • • Option D. Pneumonia : A respiratory condition that does not cause free air under the diaphragm.
  • • Option D. Pneumonia
  • • respiratory condition
  • • not cause free air

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and radiographic findings of free air under the diaphragm is a perforated peptic ulcer , a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain after eating a piece of steak. The pain started suddenly and radiates to his back. He also reports difficulty swallowing, and is drooling saliva. His vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lower chest and upper abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Esophageal perforation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pulmonary embolism : Often presents with chest pain and difficulty breathing , but wouldn’t typically cause difficulty swallowing or drooling.

  • • Option B. Acute coronary syndrome
  • • chest pain
  • • radiate to the back
  • • Option D. Acute gastritis : Can cause chest pain and tenderness but is not typically associated with swallowing difficulties or the radiographic signs seen here.
  • • Option D. Acute gastritis
  • • cause chest pain
  • • tenderness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of severe chest pain after eating , along with swallowing difficulties and radiographic signs of air in the soft tissues , suggests an esophageal perforation , which requires prompt medical intervention.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her gastroenterologist with a history of intermittent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss over the past several months. She reports that the pain is mainly in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen and is sometimes associated with nausea and vomiting. She has also noticed some blood in her stool. She denies any history of fever or recent travel. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant with no palpable masses or organomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). BMFT of the patient is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis in the patient shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Crohn's disease

  • • Explanation:

  • • Option C. Carcinoma of the colon
  • • localized mass
  • • narrowing
  • • lead to obstruction
  • • weight loss
  • • blood in the stool

  • • Option D. Ulcerative colitis
  • • continuous colonic segments

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of Crohn's disease is suggested by the patient's symptoms and the characteristic "string sign" on the barium meal follow-through , indicative of inflammation and narrowing in the terminal ileum .

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the gastroenterology clinic with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps for the past 2 weeks. questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and distension. He reports having constipation for the past week and has not passed gas or stool in the past 2 days. On examination, his abdomen is distended and tympanic to percussion. Digital rectal examination reveals a full rectal vault with hard stool. The patient's abdominal radiograph is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?

  • • episodic pain and a 'target sign' on ultrasound
  • • Option D. Ileocecal TB : Would show thickening of the ileocecal region and enlarged lymph nodes but does not explain the radiographic findings.

  • • thickening of the ileocecal region
  • • enlarged lymph nodes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a 'coffee bean sign' on the abdominal radiograph along with symptoms of severe abdominal pain and obstruction suggests a sigmoid volvulus , which is a twisting of the sigmoid colon that can lead to bowel obstruction .

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by ambulance following a motor vehicle accident. On arrival, the patient is alert and oriented but appears in distress and complaining of severe abdominal pain. He has multiple abrasions and contusions on his chest and abdomen. His vital signs are stable except for a mildly elevated heart rate. The trauma team initiates an extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (e-FAST) as given below. What will be your interpretation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Fast positive

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A : FAST negative would indicate no evidence of free fluid or other abnormalities on the ultrasound, which is not consistent with the presence of anechoic fluid seen in the image.
  • • Option A
  • • FAST negative
  • • no evidence
  • • free fluid
  • • abnormalities
  • • ultrasound,
  • • Option C: FAST inconclusive would suggest that the ultrasound results are uncertain or difficult to interpret , which is not the case here given the clear visualization of fluid.
  • • Option C: FAST inconclusive
  • • ultrasound
  • • uncertain
  • • difficult to interpret
  • • Option D : Fast is incomplete as it stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma, but without specifying whether it is positive, negative, or inconclusive, it does not represent an answer to the question.
  • • Option D
  • • Fast
  • • incomplete
  • • stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct interpretation of the e-FAST in this clinical scenario is FAST positive , indicative of a hemoperitoneum due to the visualization of anechoic fluid in the hepatorenal pouch , which is consistent with hemoperitoneum in a trauma patient.
  • ➤ correct interpretation
  • ➤ e-FAST
  • ➤ FAST positive

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-year-old child who suddenly develops severe, intermittent abdominal pain associated with vomiting and bloody stools. An USG was done as shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Intussusception

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Acute appendicitis typically shows a noncompressible , blind-ending tubular structure on ultrasound , which may not have the characteristic target or donut sign seen in intussusception.
  • • Option B: Acute appendicitis
  • • noncompressible
  • • blind-ending tubular structure
  • • ultrasound
  • • Option C: Meckel's diverticulum can cause complications that may lead to symptoms similar to intussusception , but it would not create the target sign on ultrasound.
  • • Option C: Meckel's diverticulum
  • • cause complications
  • • intussusception
  • • Option D: Midgut volvulus may present with severe abdominal symptoms , but the sonographic findings usually include a 'whirlpool sign', representing twisted mesentery and bowel, rather than the target sign.
  • • Option D: Midgut volvulus
  • • severe abdominal symptoms
  • • sonographic findings
  • • 'whirlpool sign',

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The likely diagnosis is Intussusception , indicated by the ultrasound appearance of the target sign , which is characteristic of this condition.

  • ➤ NOTE – Rotavirus vaccination is associated with Intussusception

questions.text: All are true about Nuchal Translucency scan except?

options.label: B
options.text: Done in neutral position in mid-sagittal plane

questions.correct_answer: D. Decreased in cases of aneuploidy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Decreased in cases of aneuploidy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The NT scan is performed between 11 weeks to 13 weeks and 6 days, coinciding with the period when the nuchal translucency can be most accurately measured.
  • • Option A.
  • • The NT scan is performed between 11 weeks to 13 weeks and 6 days,
  • • period when the nuchal translucency
  • • Option B. For an accurate NT measurement , the fetus must be in a neutral position in the mid-sagittal plane with the head in line with the spine to avoid false readings.
  • • Option B. For an accurate NT measurement
  • • fetus
  • • neutral position
  • • mid-sagittal plane
  • • Option C. The NT measurement is considered reliable and valid when the CRL is between 45mm and 84mm , as this corresponds with the specified gestational age range for the screening.
  • • Option C.
  • • The NT measurement is considered reliable and valid when the CRL is between 45mm and 84mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Increased nuchal translucency thickness on the first-trimester ultrasound is associated with an increased risk of aneuploidy and certain congenital heart defects . It is typically measured when the CRL is between 45-84mm during 11-13 weeks and 6 days of gestation . The fetus should be in a neutral position in the mid-sagittal plane for accurate measurement.
  • ➤ Increased nuchal translucency thickness
  • ➤ first-trimester ultrasound
  • ➤ increased risk of aneuploidy

  • ➤ 6 days of gestation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the breast clinic with a painless lump in her left breast that she discovered during a self-examination. On examination, a well-defined, mobile, firm, and non-tender mass of 2 cm is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The overlying skin is smooth, and there is no nipple discharge or lymphadenopathy. Mammogram is shown below. Classify the following mammography lesion as per BIRADS staging:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. BIRADS 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a well-defined round mass accompanied with coarse popcorn calcifications , typical of an involuting fibroadenoma . As a result, it is categorized as a benign lesion (BIRADS 2).

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, distention, and fever. He reports having bloody diarrhea and has been using mesalamine and prednisone to manage his condition. On physical examination, his abdomen is tender and distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory tests indicate leukocytosis and electrolyte imbalances. An erect abdominal X-ray was taken as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Toxic megacolon

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Pneumatosis intestinalis involves the presence of gas cysts in the bowel wall , which is not indicated in this X-ray.

  • • bowel wall
  • • Option B: Perforation peritonitis would show free air under the diaphragm , which is not visible here.
  • • Option B:
  • • Perforation peritonitis
  • • free air under the diaphragm
  • • Option C: Diverticulitis typically presents with localized colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat stranding .

  • • pericolic fat stranding

Educational Objective:
